title: shock poll finds 77 brits
story: Exclusive: Shock poll finds % of Brits less likely to obey Covid rules after Xmas party scandalThe exclusive Mirror survey reveals % believe Government officials did break the rules at the peak of the second wave, with % stating the incidents should be investigated by the police Image: Getty ImagesByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBoris Johnson’s efforts to tackle the new Coronavirus iant are at risk as a Mirror survey has found three in four Brits are less likely to follow fresh Covid restrictions following revelations of lockdown parties in Downing Street. The UK recorded its highest number of Covid infections since January  today and UK scientists warned millions could catch the new strain before the New Year as it will become the dominant iant in the UK by mid-December. The Survation poll for the Mirror reveals % of people are less likely to follow Covid rulesGovernment officials have broken them. The survey of , Brits online found % believe Government officials did break the rules at the peak of the second wave, with % stating the incidents should be investigated by the police.And % of Conservative voters who backed Boris Johnson in the last General Election believe the Tories think itaposs one rule for them and another for everyone . The poll comes after Professor Chris Whitty said he fears Brits will not accept new lockdown restrictions after enduring almost two years of the pandemic. Speaking to a  at the Local Government Association he added: “My greatest worry at the moment is that people…we need to do something more muscular at some point, whether it’s for the current new iant or at some later stage, can we still take people with us ” The Office for National Statisticsinfection survey found  in  people had Covid in England, in the week ending December . This equates to around , people. On Friday face masks were made mandatory in most indoor spaces including cinemas, theatres, churches and galleries.And from Monday those who can work from home are advised to do so, and on Wednesday the NHS Covid Passwill become mandatory for entry into nightclubs and other large gatherings.The PM’s spokesman slapped down rumours of a Covid ‘Plan C’ or a ‘Plan B plus’ being prepared for the New Year just in case the plan B measures did not curb the new iant. Plan B measures are set to be introduced next week, with MPs set to vote on the measures in the Commons on Tuesday. But at least  Tory MPs are set to rebel and vote against the introduction of tighter Covid restrictions, with many furious with Mr Johnson’s handling of Downing Street party revelations.  Former Tory chief whip Mark Harper said the PMaposs authority has been diminished by the Owen Paterson sleaze row and the alleged Downing Street party. He told the Commons on Wednesday: “Why should people listen to the Prime Minister’s instructions to follow the rules when people inside Number  Downing Street don’t do so ”And renowned rebel Steve Baker told the Mirror he hoped Labour would vote against the measures.But shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting slammed rumours of Labour voting against plan B restrictions in order to defeat the PM.He told BBC ’s Radio  Today programme “public health has always come first for the Labour Party during the pandemic. Despite the trouble the Government finds themselves in, public health will still come before party politics”. Sir Keir Starmer said the booster programme should have been ramped up weeks ago. “The Government pooh-poohed that it’s now doing it but again, as ever, too late, he added.The Survation study put Labour on a six-point lead over the Conservatives, which suggests voters have lost faith in Mr Johnsonaposs handling of the pandemic following the party scandal. Since the Mirror first revealed parties were held at the Prime Ministeraposs Number  flat in the run up to Christmas last year, the PM is now facing accusations of seven separate parties and drinks doaposs held across Westminster in November and December last year. Cabinet Secretary Simon Case is currently investigating three dates on which bashes were said to have been held in breach of lockdown rules. They are, a No leaving do on November  at which the PM spoke a No Christmas party on December  and a Department for Education bash on December . Downing Street has cancelled its Christmas party this year blaming the increase in workload for the cancelled plans. The Prime Ministeraposs spokesman said: I think weaposve made it clear since the latest situation with Omicron, obviously thataposs taking up a great deal of time at the moment. He added: Thereaposs no plans for [a party] in Number .On November , sources told the Mirror people gathered for drinks in Boris and Carrie Johnsonaposs flat above  Downing Street. And on the same day, farewell drinks were held in number s round table room - the night Dominic Cummings quit. Two weeks later on November , sources claim  to  people crammed into a room at Number  to say goodbye to top aide Cleo Watson, an ally of Cummings. Former Education Secretary Gavin Williamson has admitted to holding a canapes reception for his top team on December . Four days later people working on the London mayoral campaign for candidate Shaun Bailey held their own ‘raucous’ party. And on December  the Mirror broke the story about the Number  Christmas Party. ITV News reported on Thursday that Jack Doyle, who was then deputy director of communications at No , addressed up to  people at a Christmas gathering said to have been held on December .He offered to resign but the PM turned it down. A Number  spokesperson said Ed Oldfield is still in his position and the PM is still confident with his position, despite accepting Allegra Stratton’s resignation. title: tough covid curbs needed next
story: Tough Covid curbs needed by next week to save NHS from , patients a dayThe NHS could be overrun by , people a day being admitted with Covid unless new curbs are brought in by next week to stop the spread of the Omicron iant, it is reportedNHS staff wear PPE as they treat a coronavirus patient Image: Adam Gerrard Sunday MirrorByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments The UK government has been told that tougher Covid restrictions are needed as soon as next week to prevent hospitalisations from passing last winteraposs peak it is reported.Public health officials are advising that eventhe rapidly spreading Omicron iant causes less serious illness than Delta, it could lead to , people being admitted to NHS hospitals per day.Health Secretary Sajid Javid was given a presentation from the UK Health Security Agencythis week where he was told that “stringent action” would be needed on or before December the iant’s doubling time stays at . days,reported.Prof Neil Ferguson, from Imperial College London, whose data was key to the UK going into lockdown in March , told the newspaper that projections suggest Omicron could “very substantially overwhelm the NHS, getting up to peak levels of admissions of , people per day”. He predicted that the figure could be reached “sometime in January”the iant is resistant to existing protection and it has a similar severity to Delta - which is not yet known.  “Even the best-case scenarios involve several-fold more admissions per day than we’re getting at the moment – we are at about  right now,” he added. It comes as scientists say that Omicron could become the dominant iant by as soon as next week. And the government is currently looking at putting in stricter restrictions, it is reported. Daily Covid- cases have now reached their highest level in almost a year and the UKHSA predicted that,current trends continue, the UK will exceed one million infections by the end of the month. The UKHSA has also found that the AstraZeneca and Pfizer-BioNTech vaccines provided “much lower” levels of protection against symptomatic infection with Omicron compared to Delta.Cabinet minister Michael Gove warned of a “deeply concerning situation” after holding a Cobra meeting on Friday afternoon to discuss the latest data and the co-ordinated response across the four nations.The government said there had been a further , lab-confirmed Covid- cases in the UK and the last time a higher daily figure was reported was on January , when , cases were recorded. An additional  confirmed cases of the Omicron iant have been reported across the UK, bringing the total number to ,. Dr Mary Ramsay, head of immunisation at the UKHSA, said early data indicates that “a few months after the second jab, there is a greater risk of catching the Omicron iant compared to Delta strain”. She added: “The data suggest this risk is signicantly reduced following a booster vaccine, so I urge everyone to take up their booster when eligible.” Gove said the Omicron iant is doubling every two to three days in England “and possibly even faster in Scotland”. He added that % of reported cases in London are the new iant, and warned that evidence suggests Omicron is “more likely” than past Covid iants to “potentially” lead to hospital admissions among the fully vaccinated.  Scotland’s First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has warned of the possibility of a “tsunami of infections” from the new iant – and said she could not rule out more restrictions north of the border as a result.But so far Boris Johnson has “no plans” to go further with measures in England, amid claims that he is considering a Plan C with tougher restrictions.Now under Plan B, people are required to wear masks in more indoor spaces including museums, galleries and community centres. There will be ato working from home guidance from Monday, and mandatory Covid passports for large venues from Wednesday.The new regulations will be put to a debate and vote in the Commons next week – and with Labour ’s support they are certain to be approved despite the prospect of a large Conservative revolt.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSOmicron iantCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: what covid plan c what
story: What is Covid Plan C and what restrictions could be imposed to tackle OmicronOfficials are said to be looking at contingency plans amid mounting concern about the Omicron Covid iant. Here we take a look at so-called Plan C and what it means Image: Evening Standard   eyevineByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Dec | comments Tougher restrictions are being brought to tackle the spread of the Omicron iant as Boris Johnson implemented his Covid Plan B.The Prime Minister said on Wednesday that people in England should work from home where possible from December , while masks will be mandated in most public indoor venues from Friday. Vaccines passports will also be required for nightclubs and large events from December .But some experts have questioned whether the toolkit of measures will be enough to curb the new strain, with reports of officials drawing up Plan C with even tougher rules. Downing Street said on Friday there was growing confidence that the new iant spreads more quickly than Delta and there was some evidence of vaccine escape.Scotlandaposs First Minister Nicola Sturgeon warned of a possible tsunami of infections ahead of a four-nations Cobra emergency meeting chaired by Cabinet Minister Michael Gove on Friday afternoon. Here we sort the fact from the fiction on future Covid restrictions in England. What is Plan C  Officially, there is no Plan C. The Governmentaposs Covid Winter Plan, published in September, includes a section on Plan B which has a string of measures to imposethe Covid situation worsens. Boris Johnson pulled the trigger on Plan B on Wednesday, with masks becoming mandatory for most indoor public spaces from Friday, and vaccine passports made a legal requirement for nightclubs and large events like football matches from Wednesday. Brits will be ordered to work from home againthey can from Monday. This was thought to be enough to keep the virus at bay over the winter, along with the mass booster programme. But the arrival of Omicron has changed things. Downing Street say there is no official Plan C amid reports officials are drawing up a contingency blueprint with more restrictions. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said on Friday there were no plans to go beyond what weaposve set out already when askedthere was going to be a published Plan C. But he added: Obviously we need to keep the characteristics of this iant under review, and we would actnecessary, but thereaposs no plans to go beyond what we set out. Askedthere was a Plan C document, he said: Not that Iaposm aware of. As a responsible Government, of course, you would expect us to... we have an array, already, of options available to us in terms of what measures we can take to mitigate a growth of any iant or virus. But there are no plans to go beyond that currently. What restrictions could be included in Plan C  There are plenty of restrictions that could come in to get infection rates down. Working from home is one of the big levers the Government can pull - and this is already coming into force next week. The other big one is a reduction on household mixing, which was mooted as a contingency plan back in October. However this would be highly unpopular and it doesnapost seem to be on the cards so far. Here are some of the ideas that could be in the pipeline. Hospitality check-ins Punters could be asked to use the NHS Covid app to check into pubs and restaurants, to help contact tracers track the spread of the disease. This rule was in place earlier this year as hospitality venues reopened after lockdown but it was later abandoned. Use of the app fell after the so-called pingdemic when hundreds of thousands of people were told to isolate, leading to staff shortages across a number of industries. In August the rules were changed so double vaccinated people no longer had to isolatepinged by the app. Instead they were advised to take a PCR testthey came into contact with an infected person.  Face masks in all indoor spaces Rules on face coverings have been tightened since Friday, to cover indoor spaces such as theatres and cinemas as well as shops and public transport. But officials are said to be considering making it mandatory in all indoor spaces, which would include hospitality too. Vaccine passports in more venues From December , people will have to prove they are double jabbed or have had a negative Covid test to go to nightclubs and large events like football matches. But this could be broadened to smaller venues too. The Government has been reluctant to require vaccine passports for pubs and other hospitality venues but this could be considered.  Tougher isolation rules Self isolation rules were loosened in the summer so double vaccinated people didnapost have to stay at home for  daysthey came into contact with an infected person. Following the emergence of Omicron, the rules were tweaked so anyone who is a contact of an Omicron case has to isolate regardless of vaccination status. Bringing back the -day rule could have an impact - but it would be controversial again. What would cause Plan C to be triggered  The Government usually refuses to say explicitly what thresholds need to be met to lead to new restrictions - as the situation can change rapidly. But we can take some educated guesses based on the Winter Plan and previous lockdown rules.Throughout the pandemic, one of the key aims of restrictions is to prevent the NHS coming under unsustainable pressure. Hospitalisation rates are a key thing to watch for as large numbers of people being admitted onto Covid wards would put the health service under strain. How well vaccines are working is another critical factor, as the protection offered by the jab has allowed everyone toto some semblance of ordinary le. One of the big unknowns about the Omicron iant is how well the existing vaccines work against it. This is what scientists are currently trying to find out. The transmissibility of the new iant is also important - and how sick people are becoming from it. The new iant may seem frightening but it is worth remembering that we didnapost have the vaccine last winter, which is the best protection against the virus. When could that happen  The short answer is we donapost know. Experts are still working to understand the new iant and the scientic advice will be critical to whatever decisions the Government makes. There are some indications that the new iant may cause less serious illness than feared - but this could still have a big impact on the NHSit spread quickly and infects lots of people. There is also the political angle, as lots of Tory MPs are unhappy with the idea of further restrictions - so there could be some big parliamentary battlesthe Prime Minister tries to bring in fresh curbs. MPs will vote on Tuesday on the Plan B measures, which would be reviewed again in the New Year. However the Government can bring in additional restrictions soonerthe public health case is strong enough. title: i sterilised 32 combat excruciating
story: Exclusive: I was sterilised at  to combat excruciating period pain - Im no less of a womanChrissie Hadfield, , was  years old when she first experienced painful periods, after the birth of her first child. Shes since been offered morphine and Tramadol to cope with the pain - but was desperate for a permanent solutionChrissie first asked her GP about sterilisation when she was just  years old Image: Make The HeadlinesByTfany WallisJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsA single mum-of-two who suffered excruciating pain during her period has taken the drastic step of being sterilised - at just  years old. Chrissie Hadfield first started suffering from painful periods and ovulation pain when she was  years old, after the birth of her oldest child. Each time her period came, she describes feeling a pain like a hot blade in her abdomen, leaving her doubled over in pain and unable to stand. She would also develop thrush each month and had poly-cystic oies - one of which was inflamed. After two dficult pregnancies with her  and eight-year-old children, she decided she wasnapost going to have any more kids. And when her youngest was born, she ended up in hospital with ovulation pain. She was given morphine to manage it, but doctors couldnapost figure out what was wrong with her.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here She said: “Over the next  years, doctors put me on every form of contraception you can think of. “They thought the contraception would help control the bleeding and help control the pain but none of them did. Anything hormonal literally wiped me out. She added that her period pain was so bad, she was once given drugs only given to women in labour. Eventually, she had a non-hormonal coilfitted, but this made her periods irregular and meant she could be bleeding for  days out of the month. I could also feel myself ovulating. It felt like a metal ball on fire rolling down my abdomen and every now and again it would shoot spikes. It was extremely painful.  When she reached  years old, Chrissie decided enough was enough and, knowing she didnapost want to have any more children, she asked her GP about sterilisation. But she claims her request was met with dficulty and was told it would be tricky for a single woman of her age to have the operation. “I had to show that every form of contraception does not work for my body, the hormonal contraceptives give me mental health problems and my body rejects the non-hormonal coil, she said. “I had to keep the copper coil, so I was on some form of contraception, but I was developing bacterial vaginosis and thrush every time I had a period, so I was given antibiotics every month.” Chrissie was also worried about the long-term damage taking so much medication each month would have on her body. She explained: “Being on this much medication is unnatural. Each cycle, I was developing cysts on my oies and tubes and a scan showed I had a right inflamed oy. “So, the thought of having sterilisation to me was a dream and a way out from all the medication and no more contraception. Hopefully an end to my pain.” The dficulty she experienced with her GP was repeated when she told people she wanted to be sterilised.In a Facebook post, she wrote: Back in February I expressed that I had been put on a list to be permanently sterilised. Not just because I didnapost want more children, it was mainly for health reasons.But I expressed how other peopleaposs opinions were the reason I was keeping it quiet because everyone was so vocal about their own concerns. She added: “I haven’t given into this decision lightly, so negative comments about my age or situation haven’t helped. I know sterilisation is final, I know how old I am, and I know I have made the right choice. “I have made this decision for myself. It seems to be natural for a man to have the snip, but a woman taking ownership of her own body is frowned upon.  Even to the point I was told yesterday by another woman during my pre op assessment... you know your partner could get the snip instead  I’ve had men not even knowing what a fallopian tube is and women telling me Iaposm making a mistake because ‘whatI meet a man who wants kidsapos  Responding to these comments, Chrissie says people arenapost conscious of what she wants and needs, given that sheaposs suffered excruciatingly painful periods for  years. People just hear sterilisation and jump straight away to judgement. Especially as I was single when I started this journey, she wrote. But finally, last month, she had the operation to remove her right fallopian tube and part of her left. “Does it make me less desirable because I canapost bear children  Does it make me less than a woman  Will it make me seen as a short term partner instead of a long term partner  “What will people think  Will people pity me because of my situation  Will I regret it  But you know what, I feel relieved, and I feel empowered. “Finally, a step to try and ease the pain I have been experiencing for years. All that worry was about what other people thought again. But I have a boyfriend who is amazing, she wrote. She encouraged people not to judge what others do with their own bodies - and remember that thereaposs a lot we donapost know about what others are going through.Do you have a real le story to share  Email jessica.taylor@reachplcNow in recovery, Chrissieaposs pain hasnapost fully gone away, but itaposs more manageable. Now, she wants to promote equality around fertility issues. She said: “We are approaching . These should not still be issues women are facing to take control of their own bodies. “Nearly every woman has quoted to me, ‘my body my choice’ and I feel empathy for all the women who have thanked me for speaking up about my own experience, as it has given them confidence to speak up about their own. “Being sterilised shouldn’t make me any less of a woman,anything it gives me the ability to be more human.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSHospitalsPeriodsFertility" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: aliens already visited earth according
story: Aliens may have already visited earth, says bombshell report by NASANasa indicated it is open to the idea that extraterrestrial le exists in a report released in November under the Freedom of Information Act.Nasa is working to find unmistakable signs of le beyond Earth, it saidByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsAliens might have visited Earth already, according to Nasa which is working to find unmistakable signs of le beyond our planet. The organisation said while it is yet to find any credible evidence of extraterrestrial le, it is not closed to the possibility that aliens exist. It comes from a Nasa report released in November under a Freedom of Information request from GovernmentAttic.org. In a collection of emails, one Nasa official said the earliest alien records are probably ,BC or  AD, or not depending on what science and comments we believe. This was written in relation to the unsolved mystery of a cooking pot in China which dates back to ,BCIts owner asked Nasa for an expert opinion on the potapossUFO artwork depicting symbolic language, hidden meanings, futuristic spaceships and clothes from a vanished civilisation.The official responded: YesI was an alien who visited earth say , years ago or anytime, I too would take a simple thing in front of me like a clay pot to record my visit in multiple aposlanguagesapos or symbols and dimensions and technologies... including D, D, D, D, D, and beyond any comprehension here now.  However, he concluded that the potaposs drawing which defies the laws of physics, showing and aircraft with no motors, wings or tails, must be a unique coincidence. The document also addressed reports of unidentied aerial phenomenon, more commonly known as UFOs. It stated: “When we learn of unidentied aerial phenomena, it opens up the door to new science questions to explore. The language of scientists is data. But without access to full data, it is nearly impossible to very or explain any observation. It went on to highlight that scientic study of UFOs is facing a central problem being the lack of robust data including the lack of access to information that already exists. The revelation comes after a Pentagon report in June revealed what the US government knows about a series of mysterious flying objects that have been observed in military airspaces in recent decades. It looked at  records of sightings of what the government described as an unidentied aerial phenomenon or UFO.  Investigators were able to explain only one of those encounters which was attributed to airborne clutter. There was no evidence which pointed towards aliens or a major technological advancement by a foreign territory, such as China or Russia, as a viable explanation for the sightings. A senior US official said: Of the  reports we are dealing with here, we have no clear indications that there is any non-terrestrial explanation for them, but we will go wherever the data takes us. We don’t have any clear indications that any of these unidentied aerial phenomena are part of a foreign collection programme and we don’t have any clear data that is indicative of a major technological advancement by a potential adversary. Signicant efforts continue to track such developments and officials continue to watch that very carefully they added. Another senior official said that  of the reports show UFOs “that appear to have some sort of advanced propulsion or advanced technology. They also indicated speeds beyond what the US considers to be possible in the realms of foreign adversaries despite having a lack of propulsion or acceleration. title: baby boy born disorder rare
story: Baby boy born with disorder so rare it doesnt have a name with mum in race to save himLeo was born in March and requires round the clock care as he suffers with has epileptic seizures and low muscle tone, which means he has dficulty moving and breathingLucinda Andrews with her son Leo Image: Tim MerryByLucy Williamson:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsA mum has said she is in a race against time to save her son who was born with an ultra rare genetic disorder so rare it doesnapost yet have a name.Lucinda Andrews, , had her son Leo in March this year after a ‘perfect’ pregnancy, MyLondon reports.But when doctors noticed Leo had no muscle strength at all in his limbs, Lucinda knew something was wrong. Leo is  of  in the world to be diagnosed with a TBCD gene mutation that affects his brain, central nervous system and muscles. Leo spent nearly four months in the ICU at St. Thomasapos hospital in Lambeth, before being discharged as doctors didn’t know anything more they could do to save him.  Lucinda, who now lives in Chatham in Kent, said: “It was completely unforeseen. When he was born, I was in complete shock. The severity of it didnapost really sink in. I donapost think it really did until I saw him in the incubator with all the tubes and wires. I just burst out crying. “Nothing that could be done because of the rarity of the condition. Even specialists out there that havenapost even heard of this disorder. “Then he was discharged. I was told to enjoy the time that I have with him. Leo requires round the clock care as he suffers with has epileptic seizures and low muscle tone, which means he has dficulty moving and breathing.  Overnight he requires ventilation, which kicks in when he stops breathing when is in a a deep sleep. Lucinda previously worked in hospitality while working abroad in Canada, but came back to the UK have Leo and now is a full-time Mum to him. Despite doctors presenting the option to turn Leoaposs le support machine off in the beginning, Lucinda chose to fight for Leo. While she praised doctors who did their best for him, Lucinda says she “just couldn’t accept that there was nothing that could be done for her son. “I have sent thousands upon thousands of posts and emails all over the world to try and find someone who knew more and could help.” she said. “It’s a deteriorating condition - he will get progressively worse. It could get to the point where he’s too weak to breathe. But I want to get help before his health declines. He is definitely defying the odds right now - I hope he continues to.  “I’ve helped him with physio somewhat - I can get him as strong as physically possible, but without medical help, thereaposs only so much I can do. Due to the rarity of Leo’s conditions, there are very few medical experts on the condition. This also means she is left in limbo, with no one being able to say for sure how long Leo has left. But, despite having no medical background, Lucinda says her fight for Leo engulfed her in research in a bid to do anything that will help him. She said: “I had no medical background before this, but you do become an expert in your child. I have sat down for hours and looked at medical results. I would google each word I didnapost understand and try and put it together in a simplied form to understand what it actually means. I would research how a specic diet might help him, or supplements to make him stronger.  “But I get days when I just feel like Iaposm losing the fight for him. Iaposll pick him up from his cot and hug him and cry. But I use that for my motivation to keep going. I put all that negative stuff to the back of my mind.Lucinda has found some hope in a US biotech company who can research ‘drug re-purposing’ for Leo - whereby drugs to treat other conditions might have unintended benefits. They can also undertake revolutionary treatment to change Leoaposs failing gene to produce the protein that he is lacking. But the treatment costs £, - so she relying on fundraising.  He is my motivation to keep going, Lucinda added. Lucinda has also managed to connect with some of the other parents whose children have the same condition - of which there are only  in the world. She said: They are mostly in the States but thereaposs one in Peru, a couple in Turkey. One mum in particular I became very good friends with and we bounce ideas off each other. She’s been a real rock.You hit so many brick walls when youaposre trying to find a specialist or raise funds to help. She’s been a real pick me up to me.”You can donate to Leoaposs fundraiser andabout his story here. title: britains first vegan butcher unveils
story: Britains first vegan butcher unveils plant-based Christmas dinner - but it costs £The hamper includes plant-based "turky", "peegs in blanket" and stuffing, as well as roast potatoes, sprouts, carrots, cabbage, Yorkshire puddings, gravy, mixed green, mash and gravyRudy’s ‘Royal Christmas Meat Feast box’ serves two people Image: RudysByLucas Cumiskey:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBritainaposs first vegan butcher has unveiled a fully plant-based Christmas dinner costing a whopping £. Rudyaposs aposRoyal Christmas Meat Feast boxapos serves two people and is packed with plant-based twists on Yuletide favourites. The pricey hamper includes plant-based turkaposy, peegs in blanket and stuffing. It also contains roast potatoes, sprouts, carrots, cabbage, Yorkshire puddings, gravy, mixed green, mash and gravy. The posh pack-up will be delivered between December  and , according to the aposbutcherapos. Olie Barat raved: Such a great box. We immediately bought another for Christmas. The meat lump is amazing and great in sandwiches with pickle. The potatoes were lovely and crispy and everything was so perfect. And so easy too!  But carnivores such as Piers Morgan boycotted the business when it opened. The presenter slammed: A vegan butcheraposs shop... and people wonder why Iaposve written a book about the world going nuts.Rudyaposs is also selling another £ Christmas dinner box, which rapidly sold out after its launch last year.The business opened on World Vegan Day - November  - last year, causing queues around the block as vegans went crackers for its treats, and it sold out within one hour.  Itaposs based in leafy Islington, north London.It comes as a mum sparked a debate online, after revealing she refuses to have any non-vegan foods at her daughteraposs first birthday party.The mum-of-three explained that when her youngest was just three-months-old, they discovered sheaposs allergic to dairy and eggs and canapost eat them in any form without it making her very poorly.  So, for her first birthday, next weekend, the mum decided she wanted all food and drinks to be free from the ingredients she cannot eat, so that the youngster doesnapost end up accidentally eating something that will make her ill. We have spent so much time figuring out what she was allergic to and avoiding it, I wanted to have one day where we do not have to monitor everything she ate, the mum explained on Redditaposs AITA forum. title: can drink alcohol before after
story: Can I drink alcohol before or after my Covid vaccine - and what are the side effectsThe government is continuing to encourage people to receive their vaccines. With Christmas parties in full swing, people may want to knowthey can drink before they are given the jabCoronavirus vaccines can cause minor side effects and drinking booze may not help Image: Barcroft Media via Getty ImagesByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Dec | commentsVaccines are vitally important for tackling the coronavirus pandemic. The government hopes that despite new restrictions such as Plan B, as well as further restrictions possible in the form of aposPlan C apos, hospital admissions will be lower due to vaccinations.When the UK was forced to lockdown in  and early , most of the population was unvaccinated against the virus. Receiving the vaccine should not be too much of an inconvenience unless you are someone who may have a reaction to it. Some people have experienced brief, flu-like symptoms after receiving it, but most are expected to be fighting fit and are welcome to socialise after being vaccinated. So can you drink alcohol before and after your vaccine  Can I drink alcohol before or after having the Covid- vaccine   It is probably best to avoid drinking before and after the vaccine and you are only damaging yourselfyou have been drinking excessively. Alcohol may harm your immune response triggered by the vaccine by suppressing your immune system. If your immune system is slower to react, then the effectiveness of the vaccine could be impacted.  As for drinking after receiving the vaccine, people have been known to have side effects caused by the jab. Alcohol will not help any of these symptoms and is not a cure for feeling ill, it is just likely to dehydrate you and you will feel worse. Can alcohol affect the immune system   When a person is exposed to a virus, the bodyaposs antibodies are tasked with fighting off this illness. Healthier people with better and faster immune systems can fight viruses off more quickly. This is why older people are more at risk from viruses like Covid-, as their immune response is typically slower. Yale Medicine addiction medicine specialist Dr. E. Jenner Edelman, told Healthline: Alcohol has erse adverse effects throughout the body, including on all cells of the immune system, that lead to increased risk of serious infections.With COVID-, alcohol is likely to interfere with an inidual’s ability to clear SARS-CoV- and cause people to suffer worse outcomes. What are the side effects of the coronavirus vaccine   In February, around one in three people reported some kind of side effect from the vaccine, including some soreness around the area the needle penetrated the skin. Side effects are caused by the bodyaposs response to the vaccine and not the virus itself.Dr Anna Goodman of Guyaposs and St Thomasapos Hospital, in London, told the BBC that a heavier response to the vaccine does not mean you are more immune to the virus than others. She said: Because you have more fever, that doesnapost mean you are more immune. You canapost presume it to. People have been known to experience the following side effects caused by receiving the vaccine: Headaches Fever Muscle pain Feeling tired Nausea Chills Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Plan BImmune systemAlcoholCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: charlotte looks like mini queen
story: Charlotte looks like a mini Queen in family Christmas snap, royal fans sayPrince William and Kate Middleton have released a Christmas family photo and royal fans were quick to see how similar Charlotte looks to her great gran the QueenThe family photo on the Cambridges Christmas card Image: KENSINGTON PALACE AFP via GettyByEscher WalcottOK! reporterTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsA Christmas family snap of the Cambridges and their kids has led to royal fans quickly picking up on the likeness that Princess Charlotte has for her great gran the Queen. William and Kate released the photo on Friday afternoon with their three children and Charlotte quickly went viral as people saw the similarity to the Queen, even in the way she posed.The six-year-old was sat beside her father Prince William while her two brothers, Prince George, eight, and Prince Louis, three, were sitting nearer to their mum, reported OK! Unlike in previous years for Christmas photos the family were not dressed formally but had summer outfits on. “Delighted to share a new image of the family, which features on this year’s Christmas card,” wrote the Cambridges.  Princess Charlotte wore a blue gingham-patterned dress for the shoot and looked serene in front of the camera with her hands crossed in front of her and her long hair swept to the side. Fans quickly picked up on Charlotte looking a lot like her great grandmother, the Queen, and even had Her Majestyaposs typical pose.“What a handsome family. You can really see Queen Elizabeth in Princess Charlotte,” one person wrote on Twitter.“Charlotte is such cute princess, she is a the mini version of the Queen,” a second follower commented, while another added: “Charlotte is the image of the Queen. Adorable.”  The Mountbatten-Windsor family photo comes days after Kate hosted the charity carol event, Together at Christmas, held at Westminster Abbey in honour of those who have given their support to communities in need during the pandemic. It was a rare occasion where Kate was seen at a public event with the rest of her family including her parents and brother and sister. The Cambridgesapos kids were not at the event and a royal expert said they do not like to put them on ceremony at public occasions. The reality is that William and Kate have a rule that they do not take the children on any official engagements, said Duncan Larcombe about their absence at the carol event earlier this week. “It was on a school night and they are pretty strict. The children are in a rather strict regime so that might have been the reason, but the fact it was a televised official engagement shows that William and Kate are still reluctant to focus too greatly officially on their family and their children. title: dog walkers could face hefty
story: Dog walkers could face hefty fines of up to £, for breaking strict rulesWhile taking your dog off its leadpermitted in most UK parks and wooded areas, it is in fact illegal in some spots - something pet owners should be aware ofDogs typically need to be on a lead near roads, footpaths, carparks, play areas and certain ponds or streams at some times of the year Image: SIPA USA PA ImagesByAlice Peacock:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsDog walkers could be slapped with a hefty fine this holiday seasonthey’re not aware of strict rules which can cost pet ownersnot followed. While taking your dog off its lead is permitted in most UK parks and wooded areas, it is in fact illegal in some spots. In lieu of signs alerting you to restrictions, it is likely fine to let your four-legged friends roam free. However, dogs typically need to be on a lead near roads, footpaths, carparks, play areas and certain ponds or streams at some times of the year. Areas like flower beds, beaches and pitches are usually considered off-limits. And dog owners should keep a keen eye out for signs alerting them to the rules, in case of any other restrictions.  Local authorities also have the power to issue a Public Spaces Protection Order , or Dog Control Order, excluding dogs from certain areas or instructing owners to put them on a lead. These orders also set out rules regarding the maximum number of dogs one person can walk at one time, and rules about dog fouling. The order comes with a maximum fine of £, – which can be issued as a fixed penalty notice in place of a prosecution. Other things you could be fined for under this order include failing to remove dog faeces, not putting and keeping your dog on a lead when asked to do so, permitting a dog to enter land they’re not allowed on, and taking more than a specied number of dogs onto a land.  Other lesser-known rules include ensuring your dog is microchipped and wearing a collar and tag in public. Dog owners can face an unlimited finetheir pet is not wearing an identity disc while they’re in public, with those failing to follow these rules facing the possibility of being served with a -day legal notice. Failure to comply following such a legal notice could see owners fined up to £ per dog. title: four five adults go out
story: Four in five adults to go out of their way to be kind this Christmas, research findsFour in five adults are planning to spread Christmas cheer through kindness this year by donating to food banks and treating friends to treatsDonating to charities and food banks were the top ways people planned to be kind this Christmas Image: Getty ImagesByRob KnightGeorgie Hughes:,  Dec | commentsThe Christmas spirit is alive and well, with four in five adults planning to go out of their way to be kind over the holidays, research has found. A study of , people, who celebrate Christmas, revealed the top  ways they will be spreading cheer this month - including donating to food banks and treating others to festive drinks or a coffee. Looking out for vulnerable or elderly neighbours and singing carols in the community are also things people will enjoy doing for others during December.While spoiling friends and family in a Secret Santa, going above and beyond with Christmas dinner, and paying for someone’s meal in a restaurant made the list too. The study was commissioned by Costa Coffee which is giving away one million ‘free drink’ vouchers to selected Costa Club app members - so they can share a coffee with someone using the in-app ‘Gt a Reward’ .It also found a third are feeling more festive this year compared to last, with the average adult intending to carry out at least four acts of generosity a week over the Christmas period. A spokesperson for the coffee chain said: “The power of Christmas spirit is all about bringing people together. Whether that be in the literal sense, or in more recent circumstances, extending a token of appreciation virtually. The study also found that more than eight in  believe people are more inclined to be kind to one another during the Christmas season. Further feel-good acts include donating money or items to charity, and writing thank you notes in response to things others have done for them during the past  months. Carried out via OnePoll, the research found others intend to go the extra mile when buying gts this year. And some will purchase presents especially for vulnerable members of the community.Top  ways the nation is coming together this Christmas:. Donating money or items to charity . Donating to food banks . Treating a friend to a coffee . Buying a festive round of drinks . Writing someone a thank you note . Going above and beyond on Christmas presents . Spending time talking to those without family . Looking out for vulnerable lonely elderly people . Going above and beyond on Christmas dinner . title: how lateral flow test you
story: How to get a lateral flow test and when you should take one to check for CovidWith the introduction of Covid Plan B putting new emphasis on the need to take lateral flow tests, it is vital you know when to take them, where to get them and how to understand themNew measures, under Plan B, mean that you may need to be testing with lateral flow kits more regularly Image: In Pictures via Getty ImagesByHarry ThompsonSEO Writer:,  Dec | comments As the government introduces Plan B, the nation is once again being asked to follow measures to prevent the spread of Covid as the new Omicron iant takes hold.The new rules will see ato guidance suggesting people work from home, making facemasks a legal requirement in a range of locations including shops and public transport, daily testing for close contacts of positive cases and Covid passes for nightclubs, unseated outdoor venues of more than , people and all venues for more than ,.Talking about introducing the restrictions, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the move was the, proportionate and responsible thing to do as scientists race to uncover the dangers of Omicron.The new regulations will see increases in the number of people needing to take lateral flow tests, with Covid passes validan unvaccinated holder has ed a negative lateral flow test in the last  hours. Hereaposs everything you need to know about where to get a lateral flow test, how to read the results and more. Where can you get a lateral flow test   The best place to start is to find outyou are able to get lateral flow tests through your workplace, school or university.However, this option wonapost be available to everyone, in which case they can be ordered from the NHS website.These lateral flow tests will be delivered to your home in a matter of days. If you are unable to use the online service, you can also order them by calling the free number  between am and pm. Luckily, the tests are generally free for all purposes apart from travel. You can also go and collect them in person at pharmacies like Boots or Lloyds, as well as some community centres. Getting tests in this way is also usually free. A pack has seven tests, one for each day of the week. And, in some cases, you will be able to get two packs at once. When should you take a lateral flow test   People who are socialising often should take lateral flow tests regularly, while the new rules also create more times when you need to take them. You mainly need to take lateral flow testsyou are unvaccinated and need a Covid pass, oryou are a close contact of someone who has tested positive, in which case you will need to test every day. If you develop Covid symptoms you will need to take a PCR test, but close contacts with no symptoms will still need to take lateral flows. They are best taken when you are due to go into an area where the spread of the disease is likely to be higher, like places with big crowds or where vulnerable people will be present. Make sure you take your test no more than  hours before the event you plan to attend for the best possible protection. Test results can be registered via the barcode strip by going on the government website. When does an infection show on a lateral flow test  The following day may often be too soon to checkyou picked up the virusyou are worried you came into contact with it. Antigen tests, like lateral flows, are less sensitive than PCRs and so require a higher viral load to show a positive result - this can lead to  positives. However,you do have a positive result on your lateral flow test, you will see a line against both the aposCapos and aposTapos markers on the test, rather than just on the aposCapos marker.So, two lines, eventhey are faint, mean you are positive for Coronavirus and will need to report this on the government website.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonPublic transportPoliticsCoronavirus testing" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news kate-middletons-huge-christmas-regret-"Cheeky Princess Charlotte refuses to handover flowers after Sandringham Christmas serviceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Dec | commentsRoyal fans will be looking forward to possibly seeing the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge take all three of their children to church on Christmas morning for the first time. In , Prince George and Princess Charlotte made their Sandringham public debut when they met well-wishers after the annual religious service at St Mary Magdalene. Holding their proud parentsapos hands, the two adorable children smiled and waved to dedicated fans who waited for hours to see them - and itaposs hoped Prince Louis might join them this year. During their appearance two years ago, Kate colour-coordinated the familyaposs outfits, and they all looked very smart in dark green. And while fans around the world loved their style, it turns out that Kate really regretted her outfit choice for the day, and even told one well-wisher she really shouldnapost have worn it. Kate looked stunning in a heavy grey Catherine Walker coat, with a green hat, bag and heels.But during a quick chat with -year-old fan Rachel Anvil, she admitted it was the wrong choice for the unseasonably warm weather. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Rachelaposs mother told : Kate was talking to my daughter about clothes and how she was feeling too hot, she said aposI really shouldn’t have worn thisapos. I’m there talking to Charlotte about dolls and my daughter’s talking about fashion with Kate. It wasn’t fake it was a genuine discussion, it was about a minute but it was tailored to my daughter, it was like speaking to a friend. They are totally dferent with the public.  Meanwhile, it has been reported that the Queen will be holding her usual family Christmas gathering at Sandringham this year and may make a public appearance for the first time since early autumn.The monarch and late husband Prince Philip spent last Christmas alone as they shielded at Windsor Castle and it turned out to be their final festive season together, as the duke died aged  in April.But it appears the Covid pandemic will not force the Queen, , to cancel her usual family gathering for the second year in a row. According to reports, she is planning to host her family at her Norfolk estate and may even appear in public for the first time in months. The monarch has been resting on doctors’ orders and only carrying out light duties such as audiences since spending a night in hospital for preliminary tests on October , and later spraining her back. She is also preparing to film her Christmas Day message to the nation. title: london uks omicron hotspot variant
story: London is UKs Omicron hotspot with iant making up % of all new casesOmicron makes up % of new Covid cases in London which is the fastest growing area for the iant, along with Scotland, and there are fears more restrictions will be neededShoppers, some wearing face-masks, walk along Oxford Street in central London Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec | commentsThe British government is considering tougher restrictions after it has emerged that the rapidly spreading Omicron iant makes up % of new Covid cases in London. Boris Johnson has already introduced his Plan B which is unpopular by many members of his own Conservative Party and those in the business community where Christmas is a key period of the year.Ministers took part in a Cobra meeting on Friday where they looked at what steps can be taken to slow the spread of the Omicron iant, it is reported. Communities Secretary Michael Grove, who himself has tested positive, said that London and Scotland were hotspots and the situation was “deeply concerning”. The new data suggests that Omicron will now become dominant by as early as next week.  Last Christmas, London was badly hit by the Alpha iant and now a year on there is talk over whether similar restrictions to those in place then could be reimposed with all  boroughs having rising cases of Omicron. Data from the Department of Health shows that infections in London rose by .% in the week up to December  which was the quickest of England’s nine regions. There were . infections among , people tested which was the highest since last January. So far it has not been reflected in hospitalisations and deaths but the data typically lags behind by several weeks as it takes time for people to become seriously ill.  Mr Gove, reported the Daily Mail, said: The meeting Iaposve just chaired with first ministers of all the devolved administrations was presented with some very challenging new information.We know that we have the highest number of Covid infections across the UK recorded today since January . We know the Omicron iant is doubling every two to three days in England, and possibly even faster in Scotland. We know that % of reported cases in London are the Omicron iant and of course we only identied Omicron in this country a fortnight ago. On Friday, , new Covid infections and  deaths were reported in the UK within  days of a positive test. A further  Omicron infections were reported bringing the total to ,, according to the latest figures. In England,  additional Omicron cases were reported totalling , overall. One additional case of Omicron has been reported across Scotland which has  confirmed cases of the iant. In Wales, four further cases have been reported with the total number now standing at . No new cases have been reported across Northern Ireland where the number of infections currently remains at three. title: lonely test trace staff member
story: Lonely Test and Trace staff member, , took her own le while working from homeAlice Quaddy was found unresponsive at her flat in Cirencester by her parents after her manager at Cirencester Hospital contacted her mum to say shed not reported for workAlice Quaddy was found dead by her parentsByJohn HawkinsEstel Farell Roig:,  Dec | commentsA Test and Trace worker took her own le while working from home. Alice Quaddy had been suffering from a sense of isolation and futility before her death, her dad Brecon said.The -year-old health care assistantaposs mental health was aggravated by the loneliness she felt being on standby at home but often having little work to do, Gloucestershire Live reported. On April  Aliceaposs manager at Cirencester Hospital contacted her mum to say sheaposd not reported for work that day, Gloucestershire Coroneraposs Court heard He said that she had also missed two days earlier that week.The inquest heard that Alice’s parents went straight to their daughter’s flat, but could not get a response.Mr Quaddy used her spare keys to get into the building and on reaching her flat he peered through the letter box and saw his daughter lying leless. He called the emergency services and let the paramedics into the flat, who declared her death at .pm. Speaking after the inquest, Aliceaposs father said: Aliceaposs loss is deeply felt by everyone who knew her.To her NHS colleagues at Cirencester Hospital where she worked as a health care assistant, she was a valued and greatly appreciated member of the team whose death was all the more shocking because it was completely at odds with the Alice they knew.“She bravely fought mental illness for years and she leaves behind an unfathomable hole in the lives of everyone who knew her.Alice was seconded to the NHS internal Covid track and trace programme in Gloucestershire. She wasn’t working on the wards at Cirencester .It was meant for the best, since she was classed as vulnerable to Covid due to earlier physical health issues. Unfortunately, on many days she had few or no calls to make but still needed to remain in her flat alone on standby, a fact that doubtless increased her sense of isolation and futility that was referred to during the inquest.However, we don’t blame the NHS at all for what happened. She was part of a wonderful team. It was the response to Covid. The inquest heard from aposChange Grow Live,apos an organisation that provides drug and alcohol recovery services in Gloucestershire, and was overseeing Alice’s substance misuse after she had self-referred herself to the charity in January of this year.The organisation said Alice was being treated for her cannabis and alcohol misuse.However, her contact had been sporadic until March .At the time of her death she was not being prescribed any medication by the organisation.Alice had told them that she used around one gram of cannabis on a daily basis and only consumed alcohol socially.Alice told her support worker that she suffered from anxiety and depression, but she did not disclose any suicidal thoughts, the organisation added. Police Sergeant Portman told the inquest that he attended Alice’s address and saw her in situ. He saw that she had a number of bruises and self harm marks to her body. There were no visible wounds to suggest that she had been assaulted and no signs of forced entry to the flat. He concluded that there was no third party involvement in Alice’s death, he said.Another police officer discovered Alice’s journal, which revealed the state of mind she was in at the time.A pathologistaposs post mortem report stated that Alice had consumed alcohol and cannabis immediately prior to death and that both substances have intoxicating properties which, when combined, can alter the user’s state of mind.The pathologist believed Alice had not been taking the anti-psychotic drugs that she had been prescribed.He stated that the medical cause of death was the effects of hanging.Assistant coroner for Gloucestershire Roland Wooderson said: “It is quite clear from the evidence that Alice died on April  at her home address. I accept the medical cause of death.”The coroner then offered his condolences to Alice’s family and added that anything he said wouldn’t make anything better for them.*If youaposre struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open   on  . Alternatively, you can email jo@samaritans.org or visit their site to find your local branchRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON SamaritansMental healthInquests" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news mcdonalds-opens-first-ever-net-"McDonald’s opens net zero carbon restaurant in UK ‘first’ByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Dec | commentsMcDonaldaposs has launched its first ever restaurant which promises to deliver net-zero carbon emissions standards in the UK. The Market Drayton branch in Shropshire is insulated with British sheepaposs wool and powered by wind turbines and solar  on site. Diners queueing for their Maccas can look out for wildle in the restaurantaposs bioersity garden which collects rainwater from the carpark. It also features a Drive-Thru lane made from recycled tyres, wall art made from used coffee beans and kerb stones made from plastic bottles. The pioneering site opened its doors on December  and will act as a testing site for other industry-first creations. Plans are already in place to replicate its design with the fast food chain aiming to achieve net-zero emissions for all its , UK sites by .  It is designed to retain the familiar McDonald’s look and feel to ensure it can be effectively replicated. McDonald’s Beth Hart said the company believes its food needs to be served in restaurants that are sustainable for the future adding that Market Drayton is a big step towards making that a reality. Other climate friendly features include wall art made from recycled polystyrene cups fixed in lace with starch from McDonaldaposs own potatoes.  The building cladding is made from recycled IT equipment and white household goods like washing machines while its furniture is made from  per cent recyclable materials. McDonaldaposs Simon mcWhirter said: “The challenge of decarbonising the construction industry is a complex one. But McDonald’s commitment to building the first restaurant in the UK in line with UKGBC’s net zero carbon buildings framework is a critical first step. However, campaigners are not convinced by efforts from the food giant which has been accused of greenwashing. Greenpeace describes the concept as a PR tactic thataposs used to make a company or product appear environmentally friendly without meaningfully reducing its environmental impact. Anna Jones from Greenpeace UK told Sky News: If meat and dairy are still the main course on McDonaldaposs menu, then this new restaurant initiative can only be labelled as it is: McGreenwash. title: mcdonalds worker posed stockbroker prey
story: McDonalds worker posed as stockbroker to prey on , victims on Sugar Daddy sitesAbdul Elahi traded a terabyte of twisted images and footage - amounting to , hours of video and , photos - in just one saleAbdul Hasib Elahi was jailed for  years Image: SWNSByKelly-Ann MillsReporter:,  Dec One of Britainaposs worst online sexual predators who targeted , people across the world before selling sickening footage as boxsets has been jailed for  years. Abdul Elahi posed as a rich stockbroker on Sugar Daddy websites before blackmailing his victims into performing degrading sexual acts. The -year-old then sold the footage to paedophiles around the world in packaged boxsets - which included young women abusing themselves, siblings and their children. From the sales of his material, he would then launder the money through Amazon gt cards and buy electrical goods to sell on for cash. In one single sale, the McDonaldaposs worker traded a terabyte of twisted images and footage - amounting to , hours of video and , photos. Some of Elahiaposs victims attempted suicide after he uploaded videos of them to porn websites even bragging: Pornhub are going to love this. The warped paedophile previously admitted  online sexual offences after he targeted nearly , victims in  countries between  and . Elahi was branded depraved, abhorrent and callous by a judge as he was jailed for  years with an extended license period of eight years. Sentencing at at Birmingham Crown Court, Judge Sarah Buckingham said: Your offending is prolic and involved at least  victims.  You showed a complete and utter disregard for the welfare of every victim you manipulated irrespective of their age and there was a sadistic element to your offending. Your distribution of images was on a vast scale and allowed you to make money which you then laundered. You used multiple fake online personas to encourage women to perform sexual acts. These were not porn stars bur real women who provided the images. You were sophisticated in your operation. You wiped imagery from your phone , you packaged up these products into boxsets to be sold. There are so many examples of your sadistic and degrading exploitation and blackmail of these women it would take days to cover it all again. Your demands increased in their viciousness and brutality and however much your victims pleaded for mercy you ignored their pleas. Even when they were driven to suicide you sneered in the face of their despair. In my judgement you do pose a signicant risk of members of the public. You are an extremely dangerous inidual. You were motivated by a feeling of power and control over women, you were attracted to the financial reward you could achieve. You were utterly devoid of any empathy and regret for the pain and suffering you inflicted. Whatever your claims you did this for money I am satisfied that you harbour sadistic and paedophilic characteristics and are aroused by the abuse of children along with the abuse of women. You derived pleasure from manipulating, humiliating and distressing your victims. You were totally unmoved by their pleas to be left alone. You were prepared to, and did, offend, You showed no insight or remorse and at the same time breathtaking arrogance. You will remain a danger for some years to come. You are an example of one of the very worst type of predatory offenders ever apprehended thus far. Elahi boasted about his jet-set lestyle and how he used private jets to fly to Los Angeles – in fact, he was living with his parents and working in McDonalds. Prosecutor Andrew Langdale had branded Elahi one of the most serious sexual predators online that has been seen before this court. He added: Elahi is in a league of his own. He taught others how to abuse women and children. “This is child abuse imagery he distributed we argue he is a dangerous predator. “Abuse against others was his full time occupation. Graham Arnold, defending, said: It may be something that means nothing to the victims but he wants me to express his deepest remorse. He pushed people to do depraved things at their own great cost. He is trying to look into himself to see why and it is a very dark place. The truth is that he is struggling to find any light but all I can say on his behalf is that he is trying. Appearing alongside Elahi in the dock was Kirsty Nicholls, , who previously pleaded guilty to two charges of sexual assault of a child and one of making an indecent photo. After Elahiaposs arrest in July , officers from the NCA, the FBI, and Australian and New Zealand police found phone messages between the pair.  Elahi requested that Nicholls abused a young boy, to which she was entirely compliant and even made suggestions on how to carry out the abuse Nicholls, of Northolt, Middlesex, was jailed for six years and nine months today. Judge Buckinghamshire said: It was through Sugar Daddy websites that you encountered Elahi, the very worst type of man. One who used, manipulated and blackmailed vulnerable women to get what he wanted. The dference between you and his victims was that you were willing to do as he asked. You are intelligent and aware what you were doing was horribly wrong and in your own words sick. You became immersed in a sexualised world and became caught up in the world of online sex work without any thought of the implications. title: mum finds 5000 aldi chocolate
story: Mum finds £, in Aldi chocolate bar and there are  golden tickets still up for grabsSupermarket Aldi has hidden  golden tickets inside their Dairyfine Golden Giveaway Chocolate Bars - and there are still  more to find across the countrySian Walker found a golden ticket Image: AldiByKelly-Ann MillsReporterKieran Isgin:,  Dec | commentsA mum who bought a chocolate bar while shopping with her son was shocked to find a golden ticket inside worth an amazing £, inside. Supermarket Aldi has hidden  golden tickets inside their Dairyfine Golden Giveaway Chocolate Bars - and there are still  more to find. The tickets are worth either £, or £, and are in stores across the country. Sian Walker, from Nantwich, says the prize will mean she can build a dream extension. The -year-old said she was aposjokingapos with her son and pretended they had won - little did they know there was a genuine golden ticket inside the chocolate bar.  She said: “I couldn’t believe it. I first picked up one of the smaller bars of chocolate then swapped it for the larger one to share with my son. We were joking around pretending we had won and then when we opened it up it was such a surprise to see the golden ticket inside.  “It’s such an amazing gt and has come just in time for helping us build our dream extension on our home. Thank you so much Aldi, this really is going to make such a big dference!” All you have to do to be in for a chance of winning visit and Aldi store and buy a giant bar of Dairyfine Milk Chocolate. title: new baby joy woman who
story: New baby joy for woman who was one of UKs youngest mums at just -years-oldTressa Middleton hit the headlines when it was revealed she was pregnant despite being barely out of primary school - before it emerged she had been raped by her brotherTressa pictured with new baby Arihanna Young and new dad Darren Young at the Norton House Hotel near Edinburgh Image: Daily RecordByEmily Hall:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec One of Britainaposs youngest mums - who gave birth at just  after being raped by her own brother - has revealed she is expecting another baby girl. Tressa Middleton was raped by her own brother and became pregnant in  when she was barely out of primary school The baby was later taken away and Tressa spiralled into depression and drug use as she fought to come to terms with her horric ordeal. But she has since turned her le around with partner Darren Young and the couple revealed this week that she is around  weeks pregnant with another daughter with him. Posting a scan pic, Darren said on Facebook on December : Itaposs another girl - Arihanna is absolutely delighted.Arihanna is the coupleaposs first daughter, born weighing lbs oz in October  after a -hour labour. Tressa hit the headlines  years ago when it was revealed she was expecting a baby aged just . She had suffered a damaged childhood - her mum Tracey Tallons struggled with addiction and Tressa was forced to endure late night parties. Her older brother Jason sexually abused her from the age of seven and she fell pregnant by him when he raped her four years later.  She kept the identity of the babyaposs father a secret and the pair were taken into care until - aged  - she broke down and told a social worker what had really happened. It led to her daughter being taken away from her and then adopted in . Jason,  at the time, was jailed for four years in  after a DNA test proved Tressa was telling the truth. Tressa, of Bathgate, West Lothian, Scotland, has spoken of her upset that she was unable to keep her first baby. She told the Sunday Mirror in : Arihanna will always know she has a big sister. I talk to her about it now, even though she canapost understand. Sheaposll never be a secret. They are polar opposites - Arihanna is smiley and contented, while my other daughter was vocal and feisty. But I just know theyaposd get on.  I tell Arihannaher sister was here theyaposd play games together. I really hope that one day they can meet. It would mean the world to me. In the meantime all I want is for Arihanna to have a normal childhood, where she knows she is loved and safe. And she added: I felt pure joy the moment Arihanna was born. There were times I thought Iaposd never have another baby. But I also feel guilty, because Arihanna is with me and my older daughter is not. An -year-old is believed to be the youngest ever mother in the UK after she had a child in June this year. title: thorpe park announces new rollercoaster
story: Thorpe Park announces new rollercoaster for  - and it could be tallest in UKThe Old Town area of Thorpe Park will be the home for the new rollercoaster but the resort has confirmed it is examining what best to do with the current rides situated on the siteThorpe Park already boasts an impressive resume when it comes to rollercoasters including Swarm, pictured Image: Daniel LewisByRobert Edwards:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThorpe Park has announced plans for a brand new rollercoaster which will become the tallest in the UK, according to a website dedicated to theme park rides. The Surrey-based theme park already boasts an impressive resume when it comes to rollercoasters including both Stealth and Swarm - the last to open at the resort in .However, Thorpe Parkaposs proposed latest addition - which could be ready for  - would undoubtedly become the star attraction, reports Surrey Live.According to RideRater, the proposals were initially unveiled at a special in-person presentation for local residents on Thursday. The online website also reports that the ft rollercoaster would be the tallest in the UK, beating the ftabove ground record held by the Big One at Blackpool Pleasure Beach since .  Now further details have been shared online via the Thorpe Park website and members of the public are being asked to submit their feedback on the proposals via a public consultation. It is holding a public consultation that closes on January ,  allowing members of the public to submit feedback on the proposals. The resort said in a statement: The Covid- pandemic has had, and continues to have, a signicant impact on admission numbers to the Resort. Thorpe Park Resort aims to continue to invest in the Park’s attractions to encourage more people toto the Resort now that the tourism industry has re-opened. This key investment and the introduction of new attractions is critical to the Resort’s recovery from the Covid-related impacts on the business. With this in mind, we are delighted to announce that we are proposing to add an exciting new rollercoaster to Thorpe Park Resort’s portfolio of world-class attractions. This will be the first new rollercoaster at Thorpe Park since the arrival of THE SWARM in .
